# Decision Analysis: Hiring a VP of Engineering Post-Series A

## Step 1: Define Measurable KPIs

| KPI | Definition | Current Baseline (estimate) |
|-----|-----------|---------------------------|
| **Engineering Velocity** | Features shipped per sprint (or story points delivered per engineer per sprint) | Assume ~6 pts/eng/sprint (below healthy ~8-10) |
| **Time-to-Productive-Hire** | Weeks from decision to a new leader being net-positive on team output | N/A (no hire yet) |
| **CTO Leverage Ratio** | % of CTO time on strategic/architectural work vs. management/firefighting | Estimate ~20% strategic / 80% management |

---

## Step 2: Options (Including Unmentioned)

| # | Option |
|---|--------|
| A | **Hire external VP of Engineering** (the stated option) |
| B | **Promote an internal engineering lead** to a "Head of Eng" role |
| C | **Hire an Engineering Manager (mid-level)**, not a VP |
| D | **Fractional / interim VP of Engineering** (contract, 3-6 months) |
| E | **Do nothing — restructure processes instead** (e.g., hire a TPM, adopt better sprint practices, reduce WIP) |

---

## Step 3: Point Estimates & 80% Confidence Intervals

### KPI 1: Engineering Velocity (pts/eng/sprint, measured at 6 months post-decision)

| Option | Point Estimate | 80% CI | Rationale |
|--------|---------------|--------|-----------|
| A. External VP Eng | 9.0 | [6.0 – 11.0] | High ceiling if great hire; wide range because of culture/fit risk and long ramp |
| B. Promote Internal | 8.5 | [7.0 – 10.0] | Narrower CI — known quantity, but may lack senior management skills |
| C. Hire Eng Manager | 8.0 | [6.5 – 9.5] | Solves day-to-day bottleneck; less strategic uplift |
| D. Fractional VP | 8.0 | [6.0 – 9.5] | Fast impact but limited depth; knowledge walks out the door |
| E. Process Only | 7.5 | [6.0 – 9.0] | Surprisingly effective short-term; diminishing returns without people leadership |

### KPI 2: Time-to-Productive (weeks from today to net-positive output impact)

| Option | Point Estimate | 80% CI | Rationale |
|--------|---------------|--------|-----------|
| A. External VP Eng | 20 weeks | [14 – 30] | ~8-12 wks to hire + 6-12 wks to ramp. VP-level hires take longer to close |
| B. Promote Internal | 4 weeks | [2 – 8] | Already embedded; needs role definition and coaching |
| C. Hire Eng Manager | 12 weeks | [8 – 18] | Easier to hire than VP; faster ramp at narrower scope |
| D. Fractional VP | 3 weeks | [2 – 6] | Can start next week; productive within 1-2 sprints |
| E. Process Only | 2 weeks | [1 – 4] | Implement immediately; results show in first sprint |

### KPI 3: CTO Leverage Ratio (% strategic time at 6 months)

| Option | Point Estimate | 80% CI | Rationale |
|--------|---------------|--------|-----------|
| A. External VP Eng | 70% | [40% – 85%] | Maximum relief *if* the hire works; risk of CTO-VP conflict pulls it down |
| B. Promote Internal | 55% | [35% – 70%] | CTO still mentors the new lead heavily |
| C. Hire Eng Manager | 50% | [35% – 65%] | Offloads tactical work; CTO still owns org-level decisions |
| D. Fractional VP | 55% | [30% – 70%] | Good relief but CTO must still handle things a contractor can't (hiring, perf) |
| E. Process Only | 35% | [20% – 50%] | Marginal improvement; CTO still in the critical path |

---

## Step 4: Relevant Base Rates (Outside View)

- **VP Eng hire failure rate at Series A startups: ~40-50%** within 18 months (First Round Capital data, various startup postmortems). The most common failure mode is cultural misfit or role ambiguity between CTO and VP Eng.
- **Median time to fill a VP Eng role: 4-6 months** (Riviera Partners benchmark data for venture-backed companies).
- **Startups that add a management layer at 12-20 engineers see ~15-25% velocity improvement** within two quarters (based on State of Engineering surveys and Jellyfish/LinearB benchmarks).
- **Internal promotions into first-time management roles succeed at ~60% rate** but with faster time-to-impact (Harvard Business Review, CEB/Gartner research on first-time managers).
- **Series A startups' #1 regret on leadership hires: hiring too senior, too early** — the role often doesn't have enough scope to retain a true VP-caliber leader (Y Combinator partner surveys).

---

## Step 5: Cognitive Biases in the Framing

| Bias | How It Appears Here |
|------|-------------------|
| **Solutionism / Hammer bias** | The question jumps to "hire a VP Eng" without diagnosing *why* engineering is slow. Is it management overhead? Technical debt? Unclear product specs? Hiring a leader won't fix a product-management gap. |
| **Title inflation bias** | At 15 people, "VP of Engineering" may be over-scoped. The actual job is closer to "Engineering Manager of a single team." Candidates who genuinely operate at VP level may churn when they realize the scope. |
| **Single-cause fallacy** | "CTO is overwhelmed" is treated as the root cause. But the CTO may be overwhelmed because of unclear priorities, missing product management, or technical debt — not purely because of people management load. |
| **Availability bias** | "Hire a VP Eng" is the most commonly discussed playbook on Twitter/podcasts for this exact stage. That doesn't make it the highest-EV move for *your specific* context. |
| **Status quo neglect** | Option E (process change) is psychologically unsatisfying because it doesn't feel like a "big move" proportional to having just raised Series A. But it has the fastest payoff and lowest risk. |

---

## Step 6: Recommendation (Expected Value Analysis)

### Composite Expected Value Score (simplified weighted sum, normalized 0-100)

Weights: Velocity = 40%, Time-to-Productive = 35%, CTO Leverage = 25%

| Option | Velocity Score | Speed Score | CTO Leverage Score | **Weighted Total** | **Risk-Adjusted*** |
|--------|---------------|------------|-------------------|-------------------|--------------------|
| A. External VP Eng | 90 | 30 | 88 | **67** | **~40** (50% failure rate) |
| B. Promote Internal | 85 | 90 | 69 | **83** | **~58** (60% success) |
| C. Hire Eng Manager | 80 | 65 | 63 | **70** | **~53** (75% success) |
| D. Fractional VP | 80 | 92 | 69 | **81** | **~65** (80% success) |
| E. Process Only | 75 | 95 | 44 | **74** | **~67** (90% success) |

*Risk-adjusted = Weighted Total × P(success) + (Baseline score of ~30) × P(failure)*

---

## ✅ Recommended Strategy: **Sequence, Don't Choose**

**Immediate (Weeks 1-4):** Execute Option E + D simultaneously.
- Hire a **fractional/interim VP Eng** (or experienced engineering coach) for 3-6 months.
- Simultaneously run a **process audit**: introduce WIP limits, clarify sprint commitments, ensure product specs aren't the real bottleneck.
- This buys you CTO relief *now* and gives you data on what the permanent role actually needs to look like.

**Near-term (Months 2-4):** Evaluate Option B.
- Does an internal engineer show leadership aptitude? If yes, promote them to **Head of Engineering / Engineering Lead** with the fractional VP as their coach.
- This is faster, cheaper, culturally safer, and reversible.

**Only if needed (Months 4-8):** Pursue Option A.
- If the role genuinely requires someone who has managed 30+ engineers, built hiring pipelines, and run multiple teams — *and you now have that scope* — then hire a VP Eng externally. By then, the fractional VP will have helped you write a precise job description grounded in real needs, not assumptions.

### Why NOT to hire a VP Eng right now:
> At 15 people, you likely have 8-12 engineers. The "VP Eng" job at that scale is really an "EM who also does some recruiting." A true VP will be bored or will try to prematurely scale process. The **40-50% failure base rate** combined with **5+ month time-to-fill** means you could easily burn 6-9 months and $50-80K in recruiting costs, end up back at square one, *and* have damaged team morale with a failed senior hire.

**The sequenced approach has the highest risk-adjusted expected value and preserves optionality — which is the scarcest resource at your stage.**
